Childhood obesity has become a national epidemic.
The healthcare industry, parents, and even former President Bill Clinton, are putting together plans to help America's children slim down.
So tell us why you wrote these books?

And they are actually two books - a girl's edition and a boy's edition - with the protagonist, the young boy or girl, facing the fact that he or she is overweight and that it's effecting every facet of his or her life.

It was really a culmination of many things in my life, starting with my own personal lifestyle of fitness and working out, coupled with some professional experiences of mine, having worked as a marketing executive in the weight loss industry for a number of years now.
And then, ultimately, having two children of my own, very young children, and finding how difficult it was for even me, as health conscious as I am and as our household is, to keep them on track.
So I figured, you know, with the knowledge that I had amassed, I had a voice and I could genuinely do something about it.
Now, your books are called, It's Not Your Fault that You're Overweight.
Does that in any way clash with an idea in your very own book that talks about taking responsibility to make the changes?
Children are really under an overwhelming amount of pressure from society, even unknowingly from their parents.
And children ten years old or less, or even teenagers for that matter, are really no match for the greatest marketing minds in the country, and that's what they're up against every day.
So in that sense, it's not their fault.
I mean, they're succumbing to the overwhelming amount of environmental stimulus, even as adults are.
And ultimately, yes, it is addressed in the book that the child has to take control of their own health situation and they better understand that it is, in fact, in their power to do so.
Why did you write a book for children when, in fact, it's their parents who are making most of the choices?

Because children, even at a very young adolescent age, are able to make choices for themselves and to understand, at the end of the day, it's about helping the child make the connection between lifestyle and health.

Even parents who go that extra step to say, you know, you must drink your milk, may not go that extra step in explaining to the child why should you drink that milk - that it has calcium and it makes your bones strong.
Children need to make those connections, and very subtly, the book is for parents, as well.
But there's absolutely nothing, zero, in the marketplace today, that speaks to children on their level in an adolescent tone from a peer's perspective based on issues that matter to children.
Of course, health themes are addressed, as are peer pressure and teasing, and they can't wear the same clothes; and things that are going to resonate with the child.
Give us a sense of some of the actual health risks for children being overweight.
Well, the most common one, and the one that's really getting the most media attention right now, and it's a huge risk, is Type II diabetes.
Once really a disease exclusive to adults, it's now becoming pervasive among adolescents.
It doesn't end with diabetes, I must say.
Blood pressure, cholesterol issues, there's any number of health issues that are the result of an overweight or obese condition.
